On Rényi Differential Privacy
in Statistics-Based Synthetic Data Generation

Takayuki Miura 11    Toshiki Shibahara 11    Masanobu Kii 11    Atsunori Ichikawa 11    Juko Yamamoto 11    Koji Chida 22
Abstract

Privacy protection with synthetic data generation often uses differentially private statistics and model parameters to quantitatively express theoretical security. However, these methods do not take into account privacy protection due to the randomness of data generation. In this paper, we theoretically evaluate Rényi differential privacy of the randomness in data generation of a synthetic data generation method that uses the mean vector and the covariance matrix of an original dataset. Specifically, for a fixed α>1𝛼1\alpha>1, we show the condition of ε𝜀\varepsilon such that the synthetic data generation satisfies (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-Rényi differential privacy under a bounded neighboring condition and an unbounded neighboring condition, respectively. In particular, under the unbounded condition, when the size of the original dataset and synthetic dataset is 10 million, the mechanism satisfies (4,0.576)40.576(4,0.576)-Rényi differential privacy. We also show that when we translate it into the traditional (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy, the mechanism satisfies (4.00,10−10)4.00superscript1010(4.00,10^{-10})-differential privacy.

keywords:
synthetic data generation Rényi differential privacy privacy protection

1 Introduction

Personal data is expected to be utilized in various fields such as finance, healthcare, and medicine, but sharing personal data collected by one organization with another organization requires attention to individual privacy. Traditional anonymization techniques such as k𝑘k-anonymization [40] and randomized response [43] have struggled to find a good trade-off between utility and privacy for high-dimensional data [2]. In contrast, a synthetic data generation technique has emerged as a privacy protection method that preserves data utility even for high-dimensional data such as images and tabular data with multi-attributes [6]. In synthetic data generation, values, which we call generative parameters, are extracted from the original raw dataset, and then synthetic data are generated randomly as shown in Fig. 1(a). The synthetic data are the same format as the original data and statistically similar to them. Typical generative parameters are statistics of original data and trained parameters of deep neural networks [38, 26, 5, 15, 45, 46, 30, 17, 44, 24, 36]. After the synthetic data are generated, they are shared with other organizations, but the generative parameters are typically discarded without being disclosed.

To guarantee privacy protection theoretically, differential privacy [11] is used as a standard framework. By adding randomness in generative parameter calculation, the generative parameters become differentially private [29, 45, 1]. The post-processing property of differential privacy guarantees that synthetic data generated with differentially private generative parameters also satisfy differential privacy as shown in Fig. 1(b). Although the synthetic data generated with non-differentially private generative parameters have high utility, those with differentially private parameters are known to have lower utility [41].

We address this problem by evaluating differential privacy of randomness in data generation when using non-differentially private generative parameters. As mentioned above, in the context of anonymization, the generative parameters are often discarded without disclosing them to the public. When the output is not generative parameters but only synthetic data, we can consider that it has already been protected by the randomness even if the generative parameters are not protected with differential privacy as shown in Fig. 1(a). If privacy protection in data generation is quantitatively evaluated, theoretically guaranteed synthetic data can be obtained without degrading the utility. Moreover, by incorporating this result into traditional methods, we expect to keep the same level of security with smaller additional randomness; that is, we can obtain higher utility synthetic data.

In this paper, we regard a record as a d𝑑d-dimensional vector and focus on a synthetic data generation mechanism with the mean vector and the covariance matrix of the original dataset shown in Fig. 2. We theoretically evaluate Rényi differential privacy [34], which is a relaxed concept of differential privacy, by randomness in generation for the method. We explicitly derive the condition of ε𝜀\varepsilon such that the synthetic data generation mechanism satisfies (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-Rényi differential privacy for a fixed α>1𝛼1\alpha>1 under the unbounded neighboring condition (Theorem 3.1) and the bounded neighboring condition (Corollary 3.2). Furthermore, we conduct a numerical evaluation with reference to the Adult dataset [9] and compute ε𝜀\varepsilon concretely. We demonstrate that when the size of original dataset is 10 million and the mechanism outputs data the same size as the input dataset, it satisfies (4,0.576)40.576(4,0.576)-Rényi differential privacy under the unbounded condition and (4,2.307)42.307(4,2.307)-Rényi differential privacy under the bounded condition (Table 1). If they are translated into the traditional (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy, the mechanism satisfies (4.00,10−10)4.00superscript1010(4.00,10^{-10}) and (7.88,10−10)7.88superscript1010(7.88,10^{-10}) differential privacy under the unbounded and bounded condition, respectively (Table 2). These values are mostly similar to ones used by Apple [4] and US Census [42].

2 Preliminaries

In this section, we introduce basic notations and concepts for later discussion.

2.1 Notations

In this paper, we denote the determinant of a square matrix A∈ℝd×d𝐴superscriptℝ𝑑𝑑A\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} by |A|:=detAassign𝐴𝐴|A|:=\det A. The transposes of a vector x∈ℝd𝑥superscriptℝ𝑑x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and a matrix A∈ℝd1×d2𝐴superscriptℝsubscript𝑑1subscript𝑑2A\in\mathbb{R}^{d_{1}\times d_{2}} are denoted by xtsuperscript𝑥𝑡{}^{t}x and Atsuperscript𝐴𝑡{}^{t}A. We assume that datasets are tabular but all discussions can be applied to other datasets such as images since we consider records as vectors. In a tabular dataset, a record is expressed as a combination of several attribution values. Each attribution value is a numerical value and normalized into a range [−1,1]11[-1,1]. Thus, a record is regarded as a vector x∈[−1,1]d𝑥superscript11𝑑x\in[-1,1]^{d}, and a dataset with n𝑛n records is regarded as D={xi}i=1,…,n∈[−1,1]d×n=:𝒟D=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1,\ldots,n}\in[-1,1]^{d\times n}=:\mathcal{D}.

2.2 Differential Privacy

In this subsection, we introduce (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy and (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-Rényi differential privacy. First, we define neighboring datasets.

Definition 2.1 (Neighboring datasets)

Datasets D,D′∈𝒟𝐷superscript𝐷′𝒟D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} are neighboring datasets if D𝐷D and D′superscript𝐷′D^{\prime} are different only in one record. When datasets have a fixed size n𝑛n, we call the neighboring condition a bounded condition [23]. In this case, neighboring means changing the value of exactly one record. When datasets have no such restriction, we call the neighboring condition an unbounded condition [23]. In this case, neighboring means either adding or removing one record.111This difference is important for the sensitivity of queries. For example, the sensitivity of the mean value query under the bounded condition is twice as large as that under the unbounded condition.

(ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy [11] is defined as follows.

Definition 2.2 (differential privacy [11])

A randomized function ℳ:𝒟→𝒴:ℳ→𝒟𝒴\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{D}\to\mathcal{Y} satisfies (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy ((ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP) if for any neighboring D,D′∈𝒟𝐷superscript𝐷′𝒟D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} and S⊂𝒴𝑆𝒴S\subset\mathcal{Y}

Pr⁡[ℳ​(D)∈S]≤eε​Pr⁡[ℳ​(D′)∈S]+δ.Prℳ𝐷𝑆superscript𝑒𝜀Prℳsuperscript𝐷′𝑆𝛿\Pr[\mathcal{M}(D)\in S]\leq e^{\varepsilon}\Pr[\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime})\in S]+\delta.

In particular, ℳℳ\mathcal{M} satisfies ε𝜀\varepsilon-DP if it satisfies (ε,0)𝜀0(\varepsilon,0)-DP.

Next, we define Rényi divergence, which is necessary to define Rényi differential privacy.

Definition 2.3 (Rényi Divergence)

Let P,Q𝑃𝑄P,Q be probability distributions on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. For α>1𝛼1\alpha>1, the Rényi Divergence of order α𝛼\alpha is

Dα(P||Q):=1α−1log(∫ℝdP(x)αQ(x)1−αdx).D_{\alpha}(P||Q):=\frac{1}{\alpha-1}\log\left(\int_{\mathbb{R}^{d}}P(x)^{\alpha}Q(x)^{1-\alpha}dx\right).
Definition 2.4 (Rényi differential privacy [34])

For α>1𝛼1\alpha>1 and ε>0𝜀0\varepsilon>0, a randomized function ℳ:𝒟→ℝd:ℳ→𝒟superscriptℝ𝑑\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{D}\to\mathbb{R}^{d} satisfies (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-Rényi differential privacy ((α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RDP) if for neighboring datasets D,D′∈𝒟𝐷superscript𝐷′𝒟D,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D},

Dα(ℳ(D)||ℳ(D′))≤ε.D_{\alpha}(\mathcal{M}(D)||\mathcal{M}(D^{\prime}))\leq\varepsilon.

The smaller ε𝜀\varepsilon is, the stronger the protection, and the larger α𝛼\alpha is, the stronger the protection. To satisfy (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RDP for any α𝛼\alpha is equivalent to ε𝜀\varepsilon-DP.

The composition theorem [12, 22] holds for Rényi differential privacy as well as (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP. Furthermore, Rényi differential privacy can be translated into (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP.

Proposition 2.5 (Composition of Rényi differential privacy [34])

Let ℳ1:𝒟→ℝd1:subscriptℳ1→𝒟superscriptℝsubscript𝑑1\mathcal{M}_{1}:\mathcal{D}\to\mathbb{R}^{d_{1}} be (α,ε1)𝛼subscript𝜀1(\alpha,\varepsilon_{1})-RDP and ℳ2:𝒟×ℝd1→ℝd2:subscriptℳ2→𝒟superscriptℝsubscript𝑑1superscriptℝsubscript𝑑2\mathcal{M}_{2}:\mathcal{D}\times\mathbb{R}^{d_{1}}\to\mathbb{R}^{d_{2}} (α,ε2)𝛼subscript𝜀2(\alpha,\varepsilon_{2})-RDP. Then the mechanism ℳ:𝒟→ℝd1×ℝd2:ℳ→𝒟superscriptℝsubscript𝑑1superscriptℝsubscript𝑑2\mathcal{M}:\mathcal{D}\to\mathbb{R}^{d_{1}}\times\mathbb{R}^{d_{2}} defined as ℳ​(D)=(ℳ1​(D),ℳ2​(D,ℳ1​(D)))ℳ𝐷subscriptℳ1𝐷subscriptℳ2𝐷subscriptℳ1𝐷\mathcal{M}(D)=(\mathcal{M}_{1}(D),\mathcal{M}_{2}(D,\mathcal{M}_{1}(D))) satisfies (α,ε1+ε2)𝛼subscript𝜀1subscript𝜀2(\alpha,\varepsilon_{1}+\varepsilon_{2})-RDP.

Proposition 2.6 (Translation from (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RDP to (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP [34])

If ℳℳ\mathcal{M} is an (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RDP mechanism, it also satisfies (ε+log⁡1δα−1,δ)𝜀1𝛿𝛼1𝛿(\varepsilon+\frac{\log\frac{1}{\delta}}{\alpha-1},\delta)-DP for any 0<δ<10𝛿10<\delta<1.

By the following lemma, the result with the unbounded condition can be reduced to the bounded condition.

Lemma 2.7 (Weak triangle inequality [34])

Let P,Q,R𝑃𝑄𝑅P,Q,R be probability distributions on ℝdsuperscriptℝ𝑑\mathbb{R}^{d}. For α>1𝛼1\alpha>1 and 1p+1q=11𝑝1𝑞1\frac{1}{p}+\frac{1}{q}=1, it holds

Dα(P||Q)≤α−1pα−1Dp​α(P||R)+Dq​(α−1p)(R||Q).D_{\alpha}(P||Q)\leq\frac{\alpha-\frac{1}{p}}{\alpha-1}D_{p\alpha}(P||R)+D_{q(\alpha-\frac{1}{p})}(R||Q).

2.3 Synthetic Data Generation with Mean Vector and Covariance Matrix

In this paper, we focus on a simple synthetic data generation with the mean vector and the covariance matrix of the original dataset ℳG:𝒟→[−1,1]d:subscriptℳ𝐺→𝒟superscript11𝑑\mathcal{M}_{G}:\mathcal{D}\to[-1,1]^{d} as shown in Fig. 2. This method is identical to the Gaussian copula [38] with the assumption that the marginal distributions are all normal distributions.

The mechanism ℳGsubscriptℳ𝐺\mathcal{M}_{G} generates synthetic data as follows. First, for dataset D={xi}i=1,…,n∈𝒟𝐷subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑖1…𝑛𝒟D=\{x_{i}\}_{i=1,\ldots,n}\in\mathcal{D}, the mean vector μ∈ℝd𝜇superscriptℝ𝑑\mu\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and the covariance matrix Σ∈ℝd×dΣsuperscriptℝ𝑑𝑑\Sigma\in\mathbb{R}^{d\times d} are computed:

μ:=1n​∑i=1nxi,Σ:=1n​∑i=1nx​xt−μ​μt.formulae-sequenceassign𝜇1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖assignΣ1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛𝑥superscript𝑥𝑡𝜇superscript𝜇𝑡\mu:=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i},\ \ \Sigma:=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x{}^{t}x-\mu{}^{t}\mu.

Next, a sample is drawn from a multivariate normal distribution 𝒩​(μ,Σ)𝒩𝜇Σ\mathcal{N}(\mu,\Sigma), and its values are cut into the range [−1,1]dsuperscript11𝑑[-1,1]^{d}.

We denote by ℳGn:𝒟→[−1,1]d×n:superscriptsubscriptℳ𝐺𝑛→𝒟superscript11𝑑𝑛\mathcal{M}_{G}^{n}:\mathcal{D}\to[-1,1]^{d\times n} the mechanism that simultaneously outputs n𝑛n records by ℳGsubscriptℳ𝐺\mathcal{M}_{G}. By Proposition 2.5, we see that if ℳGsubscriptℳ𝐺\mathcal{M}_{G} satisfies (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RDP, then ℳGnsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝐺𝑛\mathcal{M}_{G}^{n} also satisfies (α,n​ε)𝛼𝑛𝜀(\alpha,n\varepsilon)-RDP.

2.4 Properties of Symmetric Matrices

We explain properties of symmetric matrices for the proof of the main theorem.

Definition 2.8 (symmetric matrix)

A square matrix A𝐴A is called symmetric if A=At𝐴superscript𝐴𝑡A={}^{t}A holds.

Definition 2.9 (positive-definite, semi-positive definite)

For a d𝑑d-dimensional symmetric matrix A𝐴A, the following two conditions are equivalent:
(1) For all x∈ℝd\{0}𝑥\superscriptℝ𝑑0x\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\backslash\{0\}, it holds xt​A​x>0superscript𝑥𝑡𝐴𝑥0{}^{t}xAx>0 (≥0)absent0(\geq 0);
(2) All eigenvalues of A𝐴A are positive (((non-negative))).
If A𝐴A satisfies these conditions, then A𝐴A is called positive-definite (positive semi-definite).

The following two lemmas are well-known facts [18].

Lemma 2.10

Let A,B𝐴𝐵A,B be positive-definite symmetric matrices. If A​B𝐴𝐵AB is symmetric, then A​B𝐴𝐵AB is also positive-definite.

Lemma 2.11

Let A𝐴A be a positive-definite symmetric matrix. For an invertible matrix S𝑆S that is the same size as A𝐴A, St​A​Ssuperscript𝑆𝑡𝐴𝑆{}^{t}SAS is also positive-definite.

Proposition 2.12

Let A,B,C𝐴𝐵𝐶A,B,C be positive-definite symmetric real matrices. If A​B​C𝐴𝐵𝐶ABC is symmetric, then A​B​C𝐴𝐵𝐶ABC is also positive-definite.

Proof 2.1.

Set D:=A​B​C=C​B​Aassign𝐷𝐴𝐵𝐶𝐶𝐵𝐴D:=ABC=CBA. Since C𝐶C is positive-definite, we can obtain the spectral decomposition C:=∑i=1dλi​θi​θitassign𝐶superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡C:=\sum_{i=1}^{d}\lambda_{i}\theta_{i}{}^{t}\theta_{i}, where λi>0subscript𝜆𝑖0\lambda_{i}>0 for all i=1,…,d𝑖1…𝑑i=1,\ldots,d. Then we set S:=∑i=1dλi​θi​θitassign𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝜃𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜃𝑖𝑡S:=\sum_{i=1}^{d}\sqrt{\lambda_{i}}\theta_{i}{}^{t}\theta_{i}. We see that S𝑆S is symmetric and C=S2𝐶superscript𝑆2C=S^{2} holds. We have

S−1​D​S−1=S−1​A​S−1​S​B​S=S​B​S​S−1​A​S−1.superscript𝑆1𝐷superscript𝑆1superscript𝑆1𝐴superscript𝑆1𝑆𝐵𝑆𝑆𝐵𝑆superscript𝑆1𝐴superscript𝑆1S^{-1}DS^{-1}=S^{-1}AS^{-1}SBS=SBSS^{-1}AS^{-1}.

By applying S−1​A​S−1superscript𝑆1𝐴superscript𝑆1S^{-1}AS^{-1} and S​B​S𝑆𝐵𝑆SBS to Lemma 2.10 and Lemma 2.11, we see that S−1​D​S−1superscript𝑆1𝐷superscript𝑆1S^{-1}DS^{-1} is positive-definite. Thus, D𝐷D is also positive-definite.

3 Main Theorem

In this paper, we prove the upper bound of ε𝜀\varepsilon such that the mechanism ℳGsubscriptℳ𝐺\mathcal{M}_{G} satisfies (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-Rényi differential privacy for a fixed α𝛼\alpha. We assume that all datasets have a limitation for the minimum eigenvalue of their covariance matrices. Specifically, for a fixed σ>0𝜎0\sigma>0, we define the set of datasets as

𝒟σ:={D∈[−1,1]n×d∣z∈Sd−1,zt​ΣD​z≥σ}.assignsubscript𝒟𝜎conditional-set𝐷superscript11𝑛𝑑formulae-sequence𝑧superscript𝑆𝑑1superscript𝑧𝑡subscriptΣ𝐷𝑧𝜎\mathcal{D}_{\sigma}:=\{D\in[-1,1]^{n\times d}\mid z\in S^{d-1},{}^{t}z\Sigma_{D}z\geq\sigma\}.

We also set τ:=4​dσassign𝜏4𝑑𝜎\tau:=\frac{4d}{\sigma}.

First, the result under the unbounded condition is the following theorem. We assume that the number of records in an original dataset is n𝑛n and that in its neighboring dataset is n+1𝑛1n+1.

Theorem 3.1

Corollary 3.2

The existence of p𝑝p is equivalent to Equation (2).

4 Proof of Theorem 3.1

In this section, we prove Theorem 3.1. The following proposition is essential.

Proposition 4.1 (Gil et al. [16])

Let α>1𝛼1\alpha>1 and 𝒩​(μ1,Σ1)𝒩subscript𝜇1subscriptΣ1\mathcal{N}(\mu_{1},\Sigma_{1}), 𝒩​(μ2,Σ2)𝒩subscript𝜇2subscriptΣ2\mathcal{N}(\mu_{2},\Sigma_{2}) be multivariate normal distributions. If a matrix

Tα:=α​Σ1−1+(1−α)​Σ2−1assignsubscript𝑇𝛼𝛼superscriptsubscriptΣ111𝛼superscriptsubscriptΣ21T_{\alpha}:=\alpha\Sigma_{1}^{-1}+(1-\alpha)\Sigma_{2}^{-1}

is positive-definite, then it holds

Dα(𝒩(μ1,Σ1)||𝒩(μ2,Σ2))\displaystyle D_{\alpha}(\mathcal{N}(\mu_{1},\Sigma_{1})||\mathcal{N}(\mu_{2},\Sigma_{2}))
=α2(μ1−μ2)tΣα−1(μ1−μ2)−12​(α−1)log|Σα||Σ1|1−α​|Σ2|α,\displaystyle=\frac{\alpha}{2}{}^{t}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})\Sigma_{\alpha}^{-1}(\mu_{1}-\mu_{2})-\frac{1}{2(\alpha-1)}\log\frac{|\Sigma_{\alpha}|}{|{\Sigma_{1}}|^{1-\alpha}|{\Sigma_{2}}|^{\alpha}},

where Σα:=(1−α)​Σ1+α​Σ2assignsubscriptΣ𝛼1𝛼subscriptΣ1𝛼subscriptΣ2\Sigma_{\alpha}:=(1-\alpha)\Sigma_{1}+\alpha\Sigma_{2}.

For neighboring datasets D1,D2∈𝒟σsubscript𝐷1subscript𝐷2subscript𝒟𝜎D_{1},D_{2}\in\mathcal{D}_{\sigma}, we set the mean vectors as μ1,μ2subscript𝜇1subscript𝜇2\mu_{1},\mu_{2} and the covariance matrices as Σ1,Σ2subscriptΣ1subscriptΣ2\Sigma_{1},\Sigma_{2}. If Dα(𝒩(μ1,Σ1)||𝒩(μ2,Σ2))≤εD_{\alpha}(\mathcal{N}(\mu_{1},\Sigma_{1})||\mathcal{N}(\mu_{2},\Sigma_{2}))\leq\varepsilon, the mechanism ℳGsubscriptℳ𝐺\mathcal{M}_{G} satisfies (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RDP. Here we set

Thus, an upper bound ε𝜀\varepsilon is described by the maximum of L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} and the minimum of L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}. The outline of proof is as follows. First, by using the different record, we represent the difference between mean vectors and the difference between covariance matrices (Lemma 4.2). Next, we determine the positive-definiteness of Tαsubscript𝑇𝛼T_{\alpha} (Lemma 4.3). Finally, we compute the upper bound of L1subscript𝐿1L_{1} (Lemma 4.4) and the lower bound of L2subscript𝐿2L_{2} (Lemma 4.5).

Set #​D1=n#subscript𝐷1𝑛\#D_{1}=n and #​D2=n+s#subscript𝐷2𝑛𝑠\#D_{2}=n+s, where s=1𝑠1s=1 when we ”add” a record and s=−1𝑠1s=-1 when we ”remove” a record. The common records are denoted by x1,…,xn∈[−1,1]dsubscript𝑥1…subscript𝑥𝑛superscript11𝑑x_{1},\ldots,x_{n}\in[-1,1]^{d} and the different record by x∈[−1,1]d𝑥superscript11𝑑x\in[-1,1]^{d}. We set each mean vector as μ1,μ2subscript𝜇1subscript𝜇2\mu_{1},\mu_{2} and covariance matrix as Σ1,Σ2subscriptΣ1subscriptΣ2\Sigma_{1},\Sigma_{2}. We also denote by σm​i​nsubscript𝜎𝑚𝑖𝑛\sigma_{min} the minimum eigenvalue of Σ1subscriptΣ1\Sigma_{1}. Note that σm​i​n≥σsubscript𝜎𝑚𝑖𝑛𝜎\sigma_{min}\geq\sigma by the assumption.

Lemma 4.2 (Representations of difference)

The following equations hold:

μd:=μ2−μ1=sn+s​x−sn​(n+s)​∑i=1nxi,assignsubscript𝜇𝑑subscript𝜇2subscript𝜇1𝑠𝑛𝑠𝑥𝑠𝑛𝑛𝑠superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑥𝑖\mu_{d}:=\mu_{2}-\mu_{1}=\frac{s}{n+s}x-\frac{s}{n(n+s)}\sum_{i=1}^{n}x_{i},

Proof 4.1.

It is easily shown by calculation.

The rank of X𝑋X is one. X𝑋X is semi-positive definite when s=1𝑠1s=1 and semi-negative definite when s=−1𝑠1s=-1.

5 Numerical Evaluations

In Theorem 3.1 and Corollary 3.2, we obtain the concrete upper bounds. Thus, in this section, we compute the value ε𝜀\varepsilon concretely and observe the results.

5.1 Setting of Numerical Parameters

We set d=6𝑑6d=6, σ=0.01𝜎0.01\sigma=0.01 since the number of numerical attributions in Adult Dataset [9] is six and the minimum eigenvalue for the data normalized into [−1,1]11[-1,1] is σm​i​n=0.01subscript𝜎𝑚𝑖𝑛0.01\sigma_{min}=0.01.

5.2 Relation between α𝛼\alpha and ε𝜀\varepsilon

The relations between α𝛼\alpha and ε𝜀\varepsilon are shown in Fig. 3 (α𝛼\alpha-ε𝜀\varepsilon curves). For all curves, ε𝜀\varepsilon is monotonically increasing with respect to α𝛼\alpha. We also see that as n𝑛n increases exponentially, ε𝜀\varepsilon becomes smaller at equal intervals on a logarithmic scale. In particular, if n=104𝑛superscript104n=10^{4}, the condition in Equation (1) is

α<c:=min⁡{n+1,n2τ​(n+1)−n}≒4.1679𝛼𝑐assign𝑛1superscript𝑛2𝜏𝑛1𝑛approximately-equals-or-image-of4.1679\alpha<c:=\min\left\{n+1,\frac{n^{2}}{\tau(n+1)-n}\right\}\fallingdotseq 4.1679

and the condition in Equation (2) is

α<c22​c−1≒2.3680.𝛼superscript𝑐22𝑐1approximately-equals-or-image-of2.3680\alpha<\frac{c^{2}}{2c-1}\fallingdotseq 2.3680.

Thus, the curves stop at these values.

5.3 The Case Input and Output are the Same Sizes

For α=4𝛼4\alpha=4, the values of ε𝜀\varepsilon for which the mechanism ℳGnsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝐺𝑛\mathcal{M}_{G}^{n} satisfies (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RDP are shown in Table 1. By the composition theorem in Proposition 2.5, the values of ε𝜀\varepsilon are ones in Theorem 3.1 and Corollary 3.2 multiplied by n𝑛n. We can show that values of ε𝜀\varepsilon are within a practical range when n≥106𝑛superscript106n\geq 10^{6} under both conditions. In particular, under the unbounded condition, ε=0.5764𝜀0.5764\varepsilon=0.5764 when n=107𝑛superscript107n=10^{7}, which is very small. We also see that ε𝜀\varepsilon’s under the unbounded condition are four times larger than those under the bounded condition.

5.4 Translation into (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP

By Proposition 2.6, we see that (α,ε)𝛼𝜀(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RDP can be translated into (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP.

The values translated into (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP under the unbounded condition are shown in Table 2. When δ=0.01𝛿0.01\delta=0.01, we see that ε=7.341𝜀7.341\varepsilon=7.341 for n=106𝑛superscript106n=10^{6} and ε=1.777𝜀1.777\varepsilon=1.777 for n=107𝑛superscript107n=10^{7}. When δ=10−10𝛿superscript1010\delta=10^{-10}, we also see that ε=13.482𝜀13.482\varepsilon=13.482 for n=106𝑛superscript106n=10^{6} and ε=4.001𝜀4.001\varepsilon=4.001 for n=107𝑛superscript107n=10^{7}. These values are reasonable [4, 42].

The results under the bounded condition are shown in Table 2. When δ=0.01𝛿0.01\delta=0.01, we see that ε=16.209𝜀16.209\varepsilon=16.209 for n=106𝑛superscript106n=10^{6} and ε=3.842𝜀3.842\varepsilon=3.842 for n=107𝑛superscript107n=10^{7}. When δ=10−10𝛿superscript1010\delta=10^{-10}, we also see that ε=31.033𝜀31.033\varepsilon=31.033 for n=106𝑛superscript106n=10^{6} and ε=7.879𝜀7.879\varepsilon=7.879 for n=107𝑛superscript107n=10^{7}.

The values of ε𝜀\varepsilon under the bounded condition are about twice as large as those under the unbounded condition.

5.5 Summary of Results

To sum up the results of numerical evaluations, we see the following:

  • •

    We see that ε𝜀\varepsilon is monotonically increasing with respect to α𝛼\alpha. This result is intuitive.

  • •

    If n𝑛n increases exponentially, the curve becomes smaller at equal intervals on a logarithmic scale.

  • •

    When n=104𝑛superscript104n=10^{4}, a range where α𝛼\alpha satisfies the assumption of being very narrow. When n=107𝑛superscript107n=10^{7}, the value of ε𝜀\varepsilon is practical.

6 Related Work

In this section, we describe the related work and mention the difference from our result.

6.1 Differentially Private Synthetic Data Generation

In synthetic data generation, the post-processing property of differential privacy guarantees that synthetic data generated from differentially private generative parameters also satisfy differential privacy as shown in Fig. 1(b). Methods to generage differentially private synthetic data for tabular data are classified to two types.

The first type is also called a “select-measure-generate” scheme [29]. Statistics and (conditional) probability distributions are used as the generative parameters. Typical statistics are mean vectors and covariance matrices of original datasets. In particular, synthetic data generation with copulas has been researched actively [38, 26, 5, 15]. To learn conditional distributions, graphical models such as Bayesian networks have been applied to synthetic data generation [45, 46, 30, 31].

In the second type, generative models with deep neural networks are used to generate synthetic data. The model parameters trained with the original data are regarded as the generative parameters. By training deep neural networks with differentially private stochastic gradient descent (DP-SGD) [1], we obtain differentially private model parameters. Methods based on generative adversarial networks (GAN) such as CTGAN [44], DPCTGAN [13], CTAB-GAN [47], and CTAB-GAN+ [48], are widely used. A method based on diffusion model such as TabDDPM [25] has also attracted attention recently.

In both types of approaches, generative parameters are computed by various differentially private mechanisms [1, 32] (Fig. 1(b)). In contrast, we evaluate differential privacy of randomness in data generation when using non-differentially private generative parameters.

6.2 Privacy Attacks against Synthetic Data Generation

Many methods empirically evaluate the privacy protection of synthetic data generations from attack success rates of membership inference attacks [37] and attribute inference attacks [14]. Most of them assume that an adversary has access to the target trained model such as GAN [8, 19, 20] and diffusion models [7, 21, 10, 28].

On the other hands, there are several methods where an adversary only has access to output synthetic data. Stadler et al. [39] discussed membership inference attacks and attribute inference attacks for tabular data in such setting, and Oprisanu et al. [35] applied such attacks to genomic data. Annamalai et al. [3] conducted attribute inference with linear reconstruction in this setting.

Although these studies and ours share a common perspective in that they focus on the privacy protection of generated synthetic data alone, these studies differ from ours in that they experimentally evaluate synthetic data generation from an attack perspective. In contrast, our perspective is to prove Rényi differential privacy theoretically.

6.3 Differential Privacy of Randomness in Synthetic Data Generation

To the best of our knowledge, only Lin et al. [27] have evaluated the privacy protection by the randomness in outputs of synthetic data generations. They theoretically evaluated probabilistic differential privacy [33] of GAN-sampled data. However, the concretely evaluated bound is hard to compute since it needs a GAN’s generalization error. In addition, they assume that training datasets are far larger than the number of model parameters. Thus, their main contribution is to give the theoretical bound, but we cannot compute the bound as a concrete numerical value.

In contrast, although we focus on only a simple synthetic data generation, we give the concretely computable bound.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we evaluated the privacy protection due to the randomness of synthetic data generation without adding intentional randomness. We proved Rényi differential privacy of a synthetic data generation with a mean vector and covariance matrix (Theorem 3.1, Corollary 3.2). We also conducted numerical evaluations using the Adult dataset as a model case. Concretely, we demonstrated that the mechanism ℳGnsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝐺𝑛\mathcal{M}_{G}^{n} satisfies (4,0.576)40.576(4,0.576)-RDP under the unbounded condition and (4,2.307)42.307(4,2.307)-RDP under the bounded condition (Table 1). If they are translated into (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP, ℳGnsuperscriptsubscriptℳ𝐺𝑛\mathcal{M}_{G}^{n} satisfies (ε,δ)𝜀𝛿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP for a practical ε𝜀\varepsilon (Table 2). In future work, we will apply our evaluation method to more advanced synthetic data generation algorithms.
